What is CORS?

CORS stands for Cross-Origin Resource Sharing. It is a security concept that is part of the web application security model. In order to protect users from malicious behavior, web browsers employ security restrictions known as the Same-Origin Policy, which prevents a web page from making requests to a different domain than the one from which the web page came. 

However, this can restrict legitimate, non-malicious communication and data transfer between different origins, or URLs. CORS is a way for a server to control access to its resources by sharing them with trustworthy origins and denying them to others.

Your error, CORS Request Blocked, is due to the Same-Origin Policy. The server at the URL https://192.168.68.112:3000/api/sensor_data is not set up to accept Cross-Origin requests from the origin of your XMLHttpRequest. 

You will need to configure the server at that URL to accept Cross-Origin requests from your origin. This typically involves adding appropriate headers to the server's response. The Access-Control-Allow-Origin header is commonly used to resolve this issue. 

For instance, if you are the owner of the server running on 192.168.68.112:3000, you would have to add the following headers:

```js
response.setHeader("Access-Control-Allow-Origin", "*");
response.setHeader("Access-Control-Allow-Headers", "Origin, X-Requested-With, Content-Type, Accept");
```

This Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *  allows all domains to access the server's resources. Depending on your specific requirement you can replace "*" with your specific domain.

Remember that enabling CORS is potentially dangerous because it allows for more avenues of attack. Always ensure that your server is secure and only allows connections from trusted sources.

Sure, if you're running the server and don't want to bypass CORS for security reasons, you should enable CORS on the server side. 

Here's an example of enabling CORS in a Flask (Python) application:

```python
from flask import Flask
from flask_cors import CORS, cross_origin

app = Flask(__name__)
CORS(app, resources={r"/*": {"origins": "*"}})

@app.route("/api/sensor_data")
...
```

This opens up all resources for CORS. It allows GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS methods from any origin with the Content-Type and Authorization headers allowed.

You can replace `origins: "*"` with your specific domain to make it more secure.

Then, you can keep your AJAX call the same:

```javascript
xhr.open('GET', 'https://192.168.68.112:3000/api/sensor_data', true);
```

The HTML code you've shared will then display the graph generated by the JavaScript in your `graph.js` file, which will be able to receive data from your server. 

Remember, you would need to restart the server after applying these settings.

Configuring Flask application to allow CORS can be achieved using separate extension named Flask-CORS.

First, install the Flask-CORS extension with the following command: 

```bash
pip install -U flask-cors
```

Next, you'll need to configure your Flask application to use this extension and allow CORS for the routes that require it. You can do this globally for all your routes as follows:

```python
from flask import Flask
from flask_cors import CORS

app = Flask(__name__)
CORS(app)
```

Or if you want to enable CORS for specific route:

```python
from flask import Flask
from flask_cors import cross_origin

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/")
@cross_origin()
def helloWorld():
  return "Hello, cross-origin-world!"
```

The CORS() function takes an optional parameter `resources` which can be used to specify the path or list of paths for which CORS should be enabled.

The `@cross_origin()` decorator provides a way to add CORS support for specific view functions.
